title: Tilikum the SeaWorld orca’s cause of death revealed - National | Globalnews.ca
text:
February 3, 2017 10:39 pm Updated: February 3, 2017 10:41 pm Tilikum the SeaWorld orca’s cause of death revealed By Staff Global News 
The killer whale that became a lightning rod for keeping whales in captivity and killed a trainer during his time in B.C. has died. Linda Aylesworth has more. What is this? 
Sponsored content is written by Global News' editorial staff without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... X What is this? 
Sponsored content is written by Global News' without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... - SeaWorld officials say Tilikum , the orca that killed a trainer at the company’s Orlando park, died from bacterial pneumonia. SeaWorld spokeswoman Aimée Jeansonne Becka announced the results of a necropsy in an email Friday. B.C.’s most infamous orca dies at Orlando Sea World Marine experts are cautiously optimistic about B.C. resident orcas Tilikum had been receiving treatment for a persistent bacterial infection when he died Jan. 6. He was estimated to be 36 years old. Tilikum was profiled in the documentary “Blackfish,” which helped sway popular opinion against keeping killer whales in captivity at SeaWorld parks. READ MORE: Tilikum dead: SeaWorld killer whale that inspired ‘Blackfish’ dies at 36 Criticism over keeping orcas captive grew after Tilikum grabbed trainer Dawn Brancheau in 2010 after a “Dine with Shamu” show and pulled her into the pool, killing her. Tilikum was also involved in the deaths of two other people in the 1990s. As SeaWorld’s most prolific male orca, Tilikum sired 14 calves in the nearly 25 years he was in Orlando. © 2017 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.
